x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: Abuse of persons within college campuses and communities are common place. Campus Safe Haven seeks to provide a tool for educating, empowering, responding and removing these victims providing support and comfort by placing them in safe house.

How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

ServiceNow Field Service Management application FSM: Integrating with Customer Service with Dispatch supporting practitioners to location with up to date information.

ServiceNow Customer Service Management (CSM): Tracks victim support cases, connects users with advocates, and manages follow-ups.

ServiceNow Security Operations: Handles incident response securely and integrates with law enforcement or campus security systems.

ServiceNow IntegrationHub: Connects with third-party APIs (e.g., shelter databases, SMS gateways, GPS services).

 

Secure messaging: Encrypted chat with counselors, campus advocates, or emergency responders.

Incident logging: Victims can record events securely for future legal or medical use.

Safe house locator: Displays nearby shelters or safe spaces with real-time availability.

Operation center locator and SOS emergency button and  dedicated short dialing code, provide ease and convenience of use. 

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

GPS and mapping APIs: Integration with Google Maps, Apple Maps, or OpenStreetMap for location tracking and safe house discovery.

Secure cloud storage: For encrypted logs, messages, and user data.

Authentication protocols: Multi-factor authentication and biometric options to prevent unauthorized access.

Campus network integration and security: APIs or data feeds from campus security systems and student services.

Real-time messaging infrastructure: Possibly using Twilio or Firebase for secure, low-latency communication.

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Privacy and safety risks: Ensuring data is protected as any leak could endanger survivors and responders lives.

User trust and adoption: Victims may fear using the app or not trust its security. Building confidence through advocacy partnerships is key.

False alerts or misuse: Systems must distinguish between real emergencies and accidental triggers.

Safe house coordination: Real-time availability and capacity data from shelters may be hard to standardize or access.

Legal and ethical compliance: Must comply with HIPAA, FERPA, and other privacy laws, especially on campuses.
